headline: Walmart Walks the DEI Tightrope in Latest Proxy Statement
summary: Advocacy-oriented shareholders are taking the DEI fight to Walmart’s annual shareholder meeting.  Walmart  released its proxy statement Thursday evening ahead of its annual meeting on June 5.  Facing conservative backlash, Walmart rolled back some of its DEI initiatives last fall, including racial equity training for staff and evaluating programs meant to increase the diversity of its suppliers.

Facing conservative backlash, Walmart rolled back some of its DEI initiatives last fall, including racial equity training for staff and evaluating programs meant to increase the diversity of its suppliers.

headline: 3 Dividend Kings That Have Raised Their Payouts in 2025
summary: If you want to collect a lot of dividend income, it's important to focus on more than just a stock's current yield.  Stocks that consistently grow their payouts over the years can be far more valuable investments to hang on to because that can ensure your dividend income is rising, possibly at a higher rate than inflation.  Three stocks which have impressive track records for dividend growth are Walmart (NYSE: WMT), Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: JNJ), and Procter & Gamble (NYSE: PG).

raw.headline: 3 Dividend Kings That Have Raised Their Payouts in 2025
raw.summary: If you want to collect a lot of dividend income, it's important to focus on more than just a stock's current yield.  Stocks that consistently grow their payouts over the years can be far more valuable investments to hang on to because that can ensure your dividend income is rising, possibly at a higher rate than inflation.  Three stocks which have impressive track records for dividend growth are Walmart (NYSE: WMT), Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: JNJ), and Procter & Gamble (NYSE: PG).

headline: Q1 earnings trends: Companies pulling outlooks due to tariff risks
summary: Pulling guidance has become a common theme of the first quarter earnings season, with Tesla (TSLA), Walmart (WMT), Delta (DAL), and others among the companies withdrawing their previous outlook. Other companies, like GE Vernova (GEV) and Norfolk Southern (NSC), reaffirmed guidance but acknowledged the cost of tariffs. Watch the video above to hear more from Julie Hyman and Roundhill Investments CEO Dave Mazza on Market Domination. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Analysis-Nestle, rivals ease US price hikes in bid for anxious American shopper
summary: LONDON (Reuters) -Household goods and packaged food makers are easing U.S. price increases to avoid losing American shoppers to retailers' less expensive private-label brands as a global trade war tests the limits of their pricing power at grocery stores.  U.S. President Donald Trump has imposed broad tariffs on several countries around the world in recent months, sparking worries that the U.S. economy will be pushed into recession, with commodities and basic utilities becoming more expensive.  Trump met with major retailers, including Walmart and Target on Monday to discuss the tariffs' impact on their imports.

raw.headline: Analysis-Nestle, rivals ease US price hikes in bid for anxious American shopper

U.S. President Donald Trump has imposed broad tariffs on several countries around the world in recent months, sparking worries that the U.S. economy will be pushed into recession, with commodities and basic utilities becoming more expensive.  Trump met with major retailers, including Walmart and Target on Monday to discuss the tariffs' impact on their imports.
